text: in this demo I'll show you how to create
HTTP live streaming or hls outputs from
Amazon elastic
transcoder this is the Management
console I'll start by creating a new
transcoding pipeline I'll give it a
name and I'll choose my input bucket
where my input files are located
each transcoding pipeline has a role
associated with it which defines the
permissions for the input and output
files we'll use the default roll here
now I'll select the output bucket which
is where my transcoded files will
live I'm going to select my S3 storage
class I can choose from either standard
or reduced redundancy storage classes
and I'll add permissions
I'm going to make my files available to
everyone so I'll choose an S3 group I'll
choose all users and I'll make them open
or downloadable by everyone now I'll do
the same thing for my thumbnails so
choose the bucket choose the storage
class and select the
permissions I'll create the
pipeline now we'll go and create a
transcoding job in that pipeline that I
just
created I'll choose my input
file and now I'll type in my output key
prefix this is going to be prefixed to
every output that I create this is
really useful if you're using if you're
generating multiple outputs because I
can actually create all of those outputs
in a particular uh location within my S3
buckets using that for/
character I'll choose a transcoding
preset and in this case I'll choose one
of the hls transcoding presets uh the
one I'll enter an output key this is the
name of the output file which will
automatically have a TS attached to it
so I don't need to add that here and now
I need to enter the segment duration the
segment duration is the uh length in
seconds of the hls chunk that's actually
generated so I'll choose 10 seconds here
which is the
standard and now I'll go off and add
another output this time picking a
different hls preset I'll choose the 1
megabit one
type in a different output
key and the segment duration now for a
multi-bit rate file set I do want to use
the same segment duration for each
output now I'm just going to choose
three outputs for this demo so I'll
choose the 2 megabit one for my third
one type in the output key and again the
segment
duration so those are my three outputs
it gives me three different bit rates
and resolutions to choose from
now I will create the playlist that's
associated with those outputs and
elastic transcoder can do that for me
automatically using the add playlist
function I'll type in the playlist name
which will have an
m3u8 extension attached to it
automatically and now I'm going to
select the files that are contained with
or the outputs that are contained in
that preset so you'll see my outputs
appear in the drop down you always want
to start with the lowest bit rate first
so we'll start with the 400k the one Meg
and the two
mag and then we'll create the job with
those
settings so now the job's been
created in the jobs page I can search on
the pipeline and have a look at the job
you'll see that it's progressing and if
I click on the details I can see all of
the different
outputs as well as the playlist list
that uh I've asked to be
created once the outputs have completed
you'll see that we have the output
duration listed as well so that's the
duration of the file together with the
resolution and thumbnail pattern if I'd
specified
one so now let's go into S3 and see what
was actually created so I'll go into my
output bucket I can see there's my
prefix right there hls demo and I can
now see all of the files that have been
generated so you'll see there's the hls
demo. m3u8 which is the master playlist
you'll see there's the fragments for one
of the bit rates fragments for the other
bit rates and there's also a
corresponding M38 for each bit rate set
which is all part of the hls standard
now if I select the master playlist and
look at the properties you'll see that
there's an actual public link available
and I can take that link and I can
actually play it back on any iOS device
for instance or a u webbased player that
understands um hls and that will play
back using the hls protocol and switch
streams accordingly as it needs to now
that link is public because of how I set
my transcoding pipelines up in the first
place so that was a quick demonstration
of how to create hls file sets with
Amazon elastic transcoder try it for
yourself and don't forget to take
advantage of our free transcoding tier
of 20 minutes standard definition will
take 10 minutes high definition per
month thank you
